hero.heading: Windows & Doors Checklists
hero.copy: Updating your windows or doors? We can help you learn the basics and put together a checklist. Then when you’re ready, come talk to us at a store.
hero.direction: What do you want to learn about?

hero.heading: Appearance
hero.copy: From the frame to the finish, your entry door can be customized to reflect your personal style.
hero.direction: Consider your entry door’s appearance

inspiration.heading: Frame
copy: Frames can be painted to match your door, sidelights and transoms. They’re available in a variety of materials and performance factors, like rot resistance.

large.alt: Reliabilt Western Reflections 8-lite Simulated Divided Lite Low-E glass

inspiration.heading: Panel design
copy: Do you want one big panel or several smaller panels? Will your door have glass and panels, or no glass at all for more privacy? You can design your door to highlight your home’s architectural style and personal taste.

inspiration.heading: Color
copy: Your color options will vary based on your door material, whether paintable or stainable. Generally, darker colors absorb heat while lighter colors reflect heat. Something to consider if you live in an area with extreme temps or if the door is exposed to direct sunlight.

inspiration.heading: Texture
copy: Going for sleek and modern? Opt for smooth textures. Want your entryway to have that old-world charm? Distressed wood textures should set the tone.

large.alt: Reliabilt Western Reflections Textured Fiberglass Door Park Hill Doorglass

inspiration.heading: Protective finishes
copy: You have the option of ordering a professionally finished door with a protective paint or stain that looks sharp and will last for years. Or, you can order it unfinished and customize the look any way you want.

next.heading: Next, let’s go over some finishing touches.
next.copy: Don’t treat these details as afterthoughts. This is where style and function collide.

hero.heading: Your Checklist
hero.copy: Here's a checklist of things to consider before heading into a store. Fill it out, print it, make notes on it and take it with you.
hero.direction: Tell us about your project

instruction.title: Pro Install
content: A professional will accurately measure your entry doors for you.
You don't have to worry about accidentally voiding your warranty.
We'll clean up the mess and dispose of your old entry doors for you.

instruction.title: Measurements
content: Doing it yourself? You can add your entry door sizes below.
We recommend taking photos of your entry doors and bringing them along. Selfies are welcome.

link.text: How to measure your entry doors

next.heading: Ready to talk entry doors? So are we.

hero.heading: Double
hero.copy: These formal entry doors instantly add sophistication and elegance to your foyer.
hero.direction: Take a closer look at double doors.

inspiration.heading: Left, right, in or out.
copy: If you’re replacing a double door, you need to know whether your old doors swung in or out and what side of the doors the handles were on. If you’re building your house, you can decide all of the above.

large.alt: Reliabilt Western Reflections Leighton Patina Caming

inspiration.heading: Two doors. Twice the charm.
copy: Double doors are an elegant and practical way to maximize space and sunlight. For entryways with less clearance, a fixed door can remain closed while the other door allows for entry.

next.heading: Next, let’s go over sidelights and transoms.
next.copy: Don’t make your door do all the heavy lifting. Add sidelights and transoms to enhance your entryway’s look.

hero.heading: Durability & Impact
hero.copy: From hurricane debris to the decibels of a passing airplane, there are ways to measure what can get through your door.
hero.direction: Things to consider while you shop

inspiration.heading: Cancel out the noise.
copy: The number of panes, types of coating and layers of insulation all factor into how much noise can travel through your door. A door’s Sound Transmission Class (STC) rating tells you how many decibels make it past the threshold.

inspiration.heading: Keep your A/C inside.
copy: Invest in your new entryway with protective weather strips on the top and sides and a sweep at the bottom. You can also invest in a best-in-class door sill for a strong seal that keeps moisture out and your air conditioning inside.

inspiration.heading: Be ready for Mother Nature.
copy: If you live in a coastal area, your building code might require that your entry door be able to withstand impact from severe weather. Each impact-rated door, frame, and glass panel is reinforced so that damage from wind and debris is minimized.

next.heading: Now let’s take a look at your safety and security options.
next.copy: From locks to fire-resistance, you don’t ever have to second guess your entry door’s security.

hero.heading: Energy Efficiency
hero.copy: Energy efficiency matters if you’re looking to save money on bills or maximize the comfort of your home.
hero.direction: Terms to keep in mind while you shop

inspiration.heading: Double pane, triple pane & low-E glass
copy: Double and triple pane glass can either be filled with gas or sealed with an airspace, making it harder for heat and humidity to pass through. Low-E glass has an invisible metallic coating that keeps heat inside during winter and outside during summer. Both types of glass can help cut your energy costs.

inspiration.heading: Laminated glass
copy: Laminated glass is designed to withstand impact,  reduce sound transmission and block harmful UV rays. It’s the similar to the glass used in car windshields.

inspiration.heading: Insulated glass
copy: How can glass be insulated? Well, a single pane of glass can’t. But windows with multiple panes of glass help regulate the temperature in your home year round.

inspiration.heading: Energy Star®
copy: ENERGY STAR certified doors meet all the strict energy efficiency guidelines set by the Environmental Protection Agency. There are different certification requirements for different climate zones.

link.text: Find out which zone you're in.

next.heading: Now, let’s talk about durability and impact.
next.copy: From hurricane debris to the decibels of a passing airplane, there are ways to measure what can get through your door.

hero.heading: Fiberglass
hero.copy: Fiberglass doors are low maintenance, easy to paint or stain and fare well in every kind of climate.
hero.direction: Why choose fiberglass?

inspiration.heading: It’s durable.
copy: Fiberglass will never rot, warp, crack, dent or rust, which makes its life expectancy fairly lengthy. And you’ll never have to worry about extreme temps or the elements wreaking havoc on your door.

inspiration.heading: It’s low maintenance.
copy: Since the bulk of maintenance usually comes down to repairs, fiberglass’s durability makes maintenance rare, not regular.

large.alt: Reliabilt Western Reflections Textured Fiberglass Door Wyngate Glass

inspiration.heading: It’s versatile.
copy: Since fiberglass doors are moulded, you can choose from a wide variety of looks. Some even look like sanded wood. With a number of professionally finished colors to choose from, achieving the finished look you’re after should be a breeze.

next.heading: Next, let’s talk about wood.
next.copy: Wood doors are crafted to complement your home’s architectural style and personal aesthetic.

hero.heading: Finishing Touches
hero.copy: Don’t treat these details as afterthoughts. This is where style and function collide.
hero.direction: Finishing touches make a world of difference

inspiration.heading: How to match your home’s style.
copy: Craftsman style doors often feature a shelf below the glass. Contemporary doors are all about clean lines and simple hardware. Rustic doors can have wrought iron clavos and strap hinges.

inspiration.heading: Hardware
copy: Choosing the right hardware comes down to style and function. Do you want a handle that’s sleek and understated or one that draws your eye in? Will your hinges contrast or blend with your frame? If your door has decorative glass, you could match your hardware to the caming—those metal bars that hold textured and beveled glass in place.

large.alt: Reliabilt Western Reflections Crosslines Full Lite

inspiration.heading: Mail slot
copy: Mail slots can be installed horizontally or vertically. They come in various sizes, materials and finishes. Flaps are either manually adjustable or spring-loaded.

inspiration.heading: Peephole
copy: If you’re considering a door without any glass, think about adding a peephole so you’ll always know what’s on the other side of your door.

inspiration.heading: Doorbell
copy: Doorbells come in all shapes, sizes, styles and sounds to complement your entryway. Larger homes usually require a doorbell with a louder or longer chime.

large.alt: Jeld-Wen Stained Aurora Custom Fiberglass Double Entry Door

next.heading: Next up, let’s go over your material options.
next.copy: When you’re considering materials, think about the level of maintenance and overall look you’re after.

hero.heading: Glass
hero.copy: Elevate your entryway with handcrafted decorative glass that adds texture, privacy and personality.
hero.direction: Picture your entry door with these glass options

inspiration.heading: Decorative glass and caming
copy: Decorative glass can complement your home’s architecture and add to your curb appeal. When you’re deciding on a glass design, consider the caming, those metal bars that hold textured and beveled glass in place.

large.alt: Reliabilt Western Reflections Sonora Morelite Patina Caming

inspiration.heading: Clear vs. textured
copy: Clear glass is great when you have an amazing view. If your view comes second to privacy, textured glass options like rain glass and granite glass add character and privacy.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen Clear Glass Painted Full Lite Steel Entry Door

inspiration.heading: Privacy rating
copy: The higher the privacy rating the more privacy the glass offers. Zero means it’s completely transparent. Ten means it’s opaque.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen Fiberglass Entry Door Clear Glass Double Sidelites

inspiration.heading: Grilles
copy: Low-maintenance internal grilles add a nice design element, while external grilles have a more substantial, traditional look. Removable grilles offer easy snap-on, snap-off versatility.

inspiration.heading: Blinds between the glass
copy: Traditional blinds can be troublesome between kids, pets and dust, but they offer much-needed shade. Blinds installed between the glass give you fingertip control without any of the hassle.

large.alt: Reliabilt Western Reflections Triple-Pane Blinds Grilles Between Glass

next.heading: Now, let’s talk about your entry door’s appearance.
next.copy: From the frame to the finish, your entry door can be customized to reflect your personal style.

hero.heading: Entry Doors Checklist
hero.copy: Your entry door is an extension of your home and hospitality. We designed this guide to help you find the right one. There’s even a handy checklist here for you to fill out and bring into a store when you’re ready to shop.
hero.direction: Here’s how to shop for entry doors

cards.title: Start with the basics.
cards.copy: Not sure where to begin? By the end of this guide, you should be able to walk into a Lowe’s store with an idea of what you want.

cards.title: Make your own checklist.
cards.copy: As you’re learning about entry doors, use our checklist to keep track of things you’d like to discuss with a Lowe’s specialist.

cards.title: When you’re ready, talk to us.
cards.copy: We’ve got entry door experts ready to help you in the Doors aisle. We can give you an installation quote while you’re there.

inspiration.heading: Consider going pro.
copy: Skip the hassle of needing to accurately measure your entry door.
You don’t have to worry about accidentally voiding your warranty.
A pro will clean up the mess and dispose of your old door.

outro.heading: If you go DIY, here’s how to measure your entry door.

cards.title: Width
cards.copy: Measure the distance between the edge of one side of the door to the edge of the other side of the door.

cards.title: Height
cards.copy: Next, measure the distance between the top edge of the door to the bottom edge of the door. Don’t include any weatherproofing or sealing on the bottom of the door.

cards.title: Depth
cards.copy: Measure the width of the frame, from edge to edge, across the existing door frame. Ignore any door trim.

next.heading: Learn about our different types of entry doors.
next.copy: How your entry door functions is just as important as its style. Consider how much room you need when it opens, and how much light you want to shine through.

hero.heading: Safety & Security
hero.copy: From multi-point hardware to fire-resistance, you don’t ever have to second guess your entry door’s security.
hero.direction: Things to consider while you shop

inspiration.heading: Fire-rated doors
copy: A door and its frame together create a fire-rated system. Steel can be fire-rated as high as 90 minutes, while fiberglass is usually rated for 20 minutes.

inspiration.heading: Multi-point locking systems
copy: In addition to standard deadbolts and foot bolts, you can have a multi-point lock system installed. Its three secure locking points of engagement on the door provide added security—and peace of mind. Deadbolts and foot bolts are also great lock options.

next.heading: Before you start shopping, let’s make a checklist.
next.copy: Why not get your ideas down while they’re fresh before you head into a store?

hero.heading: Sidelights & Transoms
hero.copy: Don’t make your door do all the heavy lifting. Add sidelights and transoms to enhance your entryway’s look.
hero.direction: What to know about sidelights and transoms

inspiration.heading: Sidelights
copy: Sidelights are the windows that flank either side of your entry door. You can add one or two, and customize the size, shape and glass type to complement your door.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen Painted 2-Panel Steel Entry Door Single Sidelite

inspiration.heading: Transoms
copy: Transoms are the windows that go over the door. Like sidelights, they can also be customized to complement and even alter your door’s appearance. For instance, transoms can create an arched entrance around a rectangular door.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen Fiberglass Entry Door Clear Glass Transoms

large.alt: Reliabilt Western Reflections Astrid Decorative Glass Antique Brass Caming

next.heading: Next, let’s go over your entry door style options.
next.copy: Elevate your entryway with handcrafted decorative glass that adds texture, privacy and personality.

hero.heading: Single
hero.copy: If you’re replacing an old entry door, chances are it’s a single door since that’s what most homes have traditionally featured in the past.
hero.direction: What to consider with single entry doors.

inspiration.heading: Left, right, in or out.
copy: If you’re replacing your door, you need to know whether your old door swung in or out and what side of the door the handle was on. If you’re building your house, you can decide all of the above.

small.alt: Masonite Park Hill Craftsman Warm Wheat

inspiration.heading: One door. All yours.
copy: Your single door can be designed to reflect your personal style, no matter if that’s understated or over-the-top. You can even upgrade to a different door type for a grander entrance.

next.heading: Next, let’s look at double doors.
next.copy: These formal entry doors add sophistication and elegance to your foyer.

hero.heading: Steel
hero.copy: Steel doors are known for being strong, low maintenance and energy efficient.
hero.direction: Why choose steel?

inspiration.heading: It’s energy efficient.
copy: Steel doors have energy-efficient foam core insulation and are fully weather stripped by the manufacturer.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen Painted Steel Entry Door Decorative Glass

large.alt: Reliabilt Western Reflections Steel Door Hampton Glass Platinum

inspiration.heading: It’s low maintenance.
copy: Steel is resistant to shrinking, swelling and warping. Its tough construction can withstand years of extreme weather conditions with minimum maintenance.

large.alt: Jeld-Wen Painted Steel All Panel Entry Door

next.heading: Next, let’s talk about your entry door’s performance.
next.copy: There’s more to your door than just good looks. It can reduce your energy costs, drown out street noise, and more.

hero.heading: Wood
hero.copy: Wood doors are crafted to complement your home’s architectural style and personal aesthetic.
hero.direction: Why choose a wood entry door?

inspiration.heading: The craftsmanship
copy: Wood has been the door material of choice throughout the ages and across the globe. It’s strong and secure yet warm and inviting. Centuries of craftsmanship have been passed down and improved upon in today’s doors.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen Golden Oak Wood Stain Panel

inspiration.heading: The easy fixes
copy: Scratches happen. On a metal door, this could be a costly and complicated fix. In a wood door, scratches can be easily repaired in no time.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen Red Mahogany Wood Stain Panel

inspiration.heading: The innovation
copy: Wood entry doors have a floating panel that allows the door to contract and expand to weather extremes and prevents splitting and cracking.

next.heading: Next, let’s go over steel.
next.copy: Steel doors are known for being strong, low maintenance and energy efficient.

hero.heading: Aluminum
hero.copy: If you’re going for beautiful, sleek and modern, aluminum doors will help you create a bright and inviting garage space.
hero.direction: Why choose an aluminum garage door?

inspiration.heading: Unique Glass Options
copy: Bring the outdoors inside with large panels of glass. Choose from transparent, opaque and tinted to add as much or as little visibility as you want.

inspiration.heading: Modern Design
copy: Brilliantly colored frames and glass options are designed to complement your home’s architecture and individual contemporary style.

next.heading: Next, let’s go over wood garage doors.
next.copy: Wood garage doors are meticulously hand-crafted with the finest milled woods for reliable performance and timeless beauty.

hero.heading: Carriage House
hero.copy: Carriage house styles bring authentic historical looks into the modern world. From looks that replicate authentic barn-style doors to more simple, yet refined carriage house styling.
hero.direction: What style of garage door do you want?

inspiration.heading: Historic style with today’s technology.
copy: Carriage house doors offer gorgeously crafted decorative options for that old-fashioned, swing-open look, with the technology and functionality you expect from a modern garage door.

large.alt: Pella Wood Carriage Garage Door Gray

next.heading: Next, let’s talk about contemporary garage doors.
next.copy: Bring the modern industrial look to your garage door with these sleek designs.

next.heading: Ready to talk garage doors? So are we.

hero.heading: Classic
hero.copy: Classic styling coordinates with any home and stands the test of time.
hero.direction: What style of garage door do you want?

inspiration.heading: Traditional and versatile.
copy: The classic style includes the most popular garage door designs that fit any price range. With more versatility in material and construction options, you’re sure to find a fit for your architectural style.

next.heading: Next, let’s talk about carriage house garage doors.
next.copy: Find historically authentic looks for your garage door, with options ranging from rustic to refined.

hero.heading: Color
hero.copy: The perfect garage door color can put the finishing touch on your home. Your color options will vary depending on your material and style.
hero.direction: See the benefits of painting color

inspiration.heading: Steel
copy: Steel doors go through a five-step finishing process, giving them four layers of protection. A wide selection of colors are available for steel doors, from white to wood grain and even two-tone paint combinations.

inspiration.heading: Aluminum
copy: Aluminum frames come in a variety of colors that can really make your house pop.

inspiration.heading: Wood
copy: Wood doors come unfinished and need to be painted or stained once they’re installed.

inspiration.heading: Vinyl
copy: Vinyl comes in UV-resistant white but can be easily painted over in any color.

inspiration.heading: DIY color tip:
copy: If you’d like to paint your garage door, be sure to use exterior latex paint. Note: painting your garage door will void your manufacturing paint & finish warranty.

next.heading: Next, let’s go over your decorative hardware options.
next.copy: Adding decorative hardware is an easy and affordable way to spruce up your carriage house garage door.

hero.heading: Contemporary
hero.copy: If the modern industrial look is more your style, these sleek door options are the perfect match for your home’s clean lines and contemporary design.
hero.direction: What style of garage door do you want?

inspiration.heading: Options that bring the light in.
copy: Contemporary garage doors offer large expanses of glass to brighten your garage. Choose how many window panels per section you prefer, and find a glass option that brings the right amount of outside light in.

next.heading: Next, let’s go over your design options.
next.copy: From windows to unique decorative hardware, you can turn an ordinary garage door into an extraordinary one.

hero.heading: Decorative Hardware
hero.copy: Adding decorative hardware is an easy and affordable way to improve the authentic look of your carriage house garage door.
hero.direction: Why consider adding on decorative hardware?

inspiration.heading: Finishing Touch
copy: Lightweight aluminum hardware simulates historic hammered wrought iron. You can also choose vinyl or stamped steel hardware.

inspiration.heading: Easy to Install
copy: Decorative hardware is easy to install on your new or existing garage door.

large.alt: Pella Carriage House Steel Decorative Hardware

next.heading: Next, let’s go over your performance must-haves.
next.copy: Do you want your garage to be well insulated, quiet and safe? It all comes down to the door construction.

hero.heading: Energy Efficiency
hero.copy: Do you want your garage to be well insulated? It all comes down to the door construction.
hero.direction: How construction layers affect energy efficiency

inspiration.heading: Construction layers
copy: The more construction layers your door has and the thicker it is, the greater the R-value will be which can help maintain your garage’s temperature. This is important if the garage is attached to your home or used as a living space.

inspiration.heading: 1-layer
copy: Steel with no insulation. Since there is no insulation layer, there’s no R-value.

inspiration.heading: 2-layer
copy: For a more insulated, quieter garage, your base layer is steel, plus you have a layer of insulation. Good R-values.

inspiration.heading: 3-layer
copy: This is the toughest, most energy-efficient option with the best noise reduction. Steel exterior plus insulation and an interior layer of steel. Best R-value.

next.heading: Now, let’s talk about how to make your garage door quieter.
next.copy: Because you don’t have to settle for a loud garage door.

hero.heading: Garage Doors Checklist
hero.copy: Are you lost when it comes to choosing the best garage door for your home? You’re not alone. That’s why we designed this guide to help you navigate the aisles and find your perfect door.
hero.direction: How to shop for garage doors

cards.title: Start with the basics.
cards.copy: Your garage door can dramatically impact your curb appeal. We’ll help you find the perfect one by going over all your options.

cards.title: Make your own checklist.
cards.copy: While your ideas are still fresh in your mind, feel free to fill out our shopping checklist and bring it with you into a store.

cards.title: When you’re ready, talk to us.
cards.copy: Our experts are ready to help you in the Garage Door Design Center at your local Lowe’s.

inspiration.heading: Consider Going Pro
copy: A pro will accurately measure your garage door for you.
They’ll clean up the mess and dispose of your old garage door.
You don’t have to worry about accidentally voiding your warranty.

outro.heading: Here’s how to measure your garage door.

cards.title: Width
cards.copy: First, measure the width of the opening at the widest point. This is the distance between the right and left sides of the finished opening. Check to see if your floor is uneven.

cards.title: Height
cards.copy: Next, measure the height of the door. This is the distance between the floor and the top of the finished opening. Measure the area between the top of the door opening and the ceiling (or the lowest obstruction from the ceiling).

cards.title: Depth
cards.copy: Last, measure the distance from the opening to the rear of the garage.

next.heading: Now, let’s go over materials.
next.copy: Each material has its own unique benefits. We’ll help you find the one that matches your lifestyle.

hero.heading: Quiet Operation
hero.copy: Tired of waking everyone up when you leave or get home from work? You don’t have to settle for a loud garage door.
hero.direction: Here’s how to turn the volume down.

inspiration.heading: Insulation
copy: The more insulation a door has, the quieter it is. For maximum performance, choose a thicker, polyurethane-insulated door.

inspiration.heading: Opening System
copy: The rollers and opener will also affect how loud your garage door is. If you use an electric opener to operate your garage door, belt drive openers are your quietest option.

next.heading: Now, let’s talk about garage door safety.
next.copy: Additional safety features can help reduce the risk of injuries.

hero.heading: Safety
hero.copy: The most common garage door injury involves fingers and hands getting caught between sections.
hero.direction: What can you do to reduce the risk of injuries?

inspiration.heading: Pinch protection gives you peace of mind.
copy: Some garage doors are designed to reduce the risk of hand injuries. If safety is important to you, consider looking for doors with pinch protection.

next.heading: Now, let’s talk about garage door wind load.
next.copy: The area you live in may require garage doors that can handle tough weather conditions.

hero.heading: Steel
hero.copy: Steel is popular due to its durability, easy maintenance and high-quality appearance. It can imitate the look of wood but lasts longer and is easier to maintain.
hero.direction: Here are more reasons people choose steel.

inspiration.heading: It lasts a long time.
copy: It’s one of the strongest, most durable and reliable materials around.

inspiration.heading: It’s low maintenance.
copy: You’ll spend more time admiring your steel garage door than maintaining it.

large.alt: Pella Steel Material Low Maintenance Garage Door

inspiration.heading: It’s attractive.
copy: The high-quality appearance of steel features state of the art wood grain embossment.

next.heading: Now, let’s go over aluminum garage doors.
next.copy: If you’re going for beautiful, sleek and modern, aluminum doors will help you create a bright and inviting garage space.

hero.heading: Vinyl
hero.copy: These rust-resistant garage doors are ideal for homes near coastal areas.
hero.direction: Why choose a vinyl garage door?

inspiration.heading: It’s rust-resistant.
copy: Vinyl garage doors are built with vinyl facing and edges on each section which seals out weather elements and won’t fade or rust.

inspiration.heading: It’s extremely durable.
copy: The type of vinyl used in garage doors is incredibly resilient and low maintenance.

inspiration.heading: It’s low maintenance.
copy: You’ll spend more time admiring your weather-resistant vinyl door than worrying about rust or damage from salt-spray environments.

next.heading: Next, let’s go over your style options.
next.copy: When we talk about style, we’re talking about designs that match the architecture of your home and individual style.

hero.heading: Wind Load
hero.copy: Your garage door is usually the largest opening in your home and the most vulnerable to damage during severe weather.
hero.direction: Why does wind load matter?

inspiration.heading: Make sure you’re ready for Mother Nature.
copy: Wind load doors are built to handle hurricane-level winds. If you live in a coastal area, your local building code requires that you have one.

inspiration.heading: Not all wind load doors are created equal.
copy: The best way to find your area’s wind load requirements is to reach out to a local building code official. Even if you’re a hundred miles inland, you might be surprised to see how strict your wind load code is.

next.heading: Now, take a minute to create your checklist.
next.copy: While your ideas are still fresh, why not jot down a checklist to bring into a store?

hero.heading: Windows
hero.copy: Without windows, your garage can be dark and dreary. Adding windows can really brighten up the space.
hero.direction: Add another layer of sophistication with windows.

inspiration.heading: Decorative Glass
copy: Textured glass offers minimal visibility into your garage. Tempered glass with baked on ceramic design resists yellowing, fading and peeling.

inspiration.heading: Decorative Grilles
copy: The most affordable option, grilles, can be easily removed and changed at anytime. All grilles are UV fade-resistant with a realistic-looking embossed wood grain finish.

next.heading: Next, start thinking about your color scheme.
next.copy: The perfect garage door color can put the finishing touch on your home’s look.

hero.heading: Wood
hero.copy: Wood garage doors are meticulously hand-crafted with the finest milled woods for reliable performance and timeless beauty.
hero.direction: Why choose an wood garage door?

inspiration.heading: Skilled Craftsmanship
copy: Wood garage doors are meticulously hand-crafted with the finest milled woods for reliable performance and long-lasting beauty.

small.alt: Pella Wood Garage Door Curb Appeal

inspiration.heading: Unlimited Door Designs
copy: Choose from one of our popular wood carriage house styles or create your own one-of-a-kind design. You can paint, stain, finish and customize your wood door to fit your unique style.

inspiration.heading: Beautiful Finish
copy: Wood doors come unfinished which allows you to paint or stain them to add warmth and beauty to your home.

next.heading: Next up, vinyl garage doors.
next.copy: These rust-resistant garage doors are ideal for homes near coastal areas.

hero.heading: Appearance
hero.copy: From the frame to the finish, your interior doors can be customized to reflect your personal style.
hero.direction: Consider your interior door’s appearance

inspiration.heading: Color
copy: Find color options that complement your home’s design—and your personal style. It’s up to you whether you’d like your doors to blend into the wall or stand out.

inspiration.heading: Frame
copy: Match your home’s architectural style with the perfect door trim. A variety of casings (visible frames) and corner blocks (carved blocks in upper corners) can be carefully fashioned as part of a comprehensive pre-hanging package.

inspiration.heading: Privacy Options
copy: Your glass selection not only affects your privacy needs, it can bring dimension, contrast and more light into your space.

next.heading: Next, let’s go over some finishing touches.
next.copy: Don’t treat these details as afterthoughts. This is where style and function collide.

next.heading: Ready to talk interior doors? So are we.

hero.heading: Environmentally Friendly Options
hero.copy: Make sure your interior doors have a positive impact on the environment, both inside and outside your home.
hero.direction: Things to look for while you shop

inspiration.heading: Sustainable materials
copy: Whether you’re drawn to solid wood or composite doors, each material has environmentally-friendly options. For example, knotty pine wood is rapidly renewable, and most composite doors are made from recycled materials.

inspiration.heading: Low emissions
copy: A new door should be a breath of fresh air. It shouldn’t make your air hazardous. Look for doors made with low emission sealants and without added formaldehyde.

next.heading: Now, let’s look at safety considerations.
next.copy: Hopefully you never have to worry about a fire in your home, but it’s always better to be prepared.

hero.heading: Finishing Touches
hero.copy: Don't treat these details as afterthoughts. This is where style and function collide.
hero.direction: Finishing touches make a world of difference

inspiration.heading: Decorative touches & add-ons
copy: Handles range in style from substantial to sleek; functions range from decorative-only to full locking mechanisms.

inspiration.heading: Hardware
copy: Choosing the right hardware comes down to style and function. Going for a contemporary look? Think clean lines and simple hardware. Are rustic doors more your style? Add some clavos (decorative nails), hinge tips or metallic inlays for an old-world look.

inspiration.heading: Router carved touches
copy: The distinctive dimensional details of router carved panels can elevate the entire look of your room. They come in raised, planked, or flat profiles and can even be matched to existing styles.

small.alt: Masonite Sand Piper Interior Routed Door

inspiration.heading: Factory finish
copy: Our professionally finished interior doors come with a protective paint or stain that looks sharp and will last for years.

next.heading: Next up, let’s go over your material options.
next.copy: When you’re considering materials, think about the level of maintenance and overall look you’re after.

hero.heading: Hinged
hero.copy: This swing-open, swing-shut style is a traditional choice for an interior door. You can buy as door only or a pre-hung unit.
hero.direction: Here are your hinged door options

inspiration.heading: Single pre-hung doors
copy: Pre-hung doors come attached to the frame with all the necessary hinges and handles. A single door can be an understated transition from room to room, or a discreet enclosure for a closet or storage.

inspiration.heading: Double pre-hung doors
copy: Great as an elegant entry to a study, dining area or anywhere you’d like to make a statement. Double doors can also bring more light into a room and unify the space.

inspiration.heading: French doors
copy: In the 17th century, French doors started out as floor-to-ceiling windows that doubled as doors. Nowadays, they’re still an elegant and practical way to maximize space and sunlight.

next.heading: Next, let’s look at sliding and folding doors.
next.copy: If you’re looking for space efficiency and style, these non-hinged door types offer form and function.

hero.heading: MDF
hero.copy: Medium density fiberboard is a durable material made from recycled wood fibers and resin.
hero.direction: Why choose an MDF door?

inspiration.heading: Durability
copy: MDF is machine dried and pressed into dense sheets. The result? A strong material that resists warping, shrinking and cracking.

inspiration.heading: Design flexibility
copy: MDF doors come in various stile and rail designs and are ready to be painted to match your home’s style.

next.heading: Next, let’s talk about your interior door’s performance.
next.copy: From noise cancellation to fire-resistance, your interior doors bring more to the table than just looks.

hero.heading: Noise Cancelling
hero.copy: When it comes to creating a quiet home atmosphere, it’s what’s on the inside (of your doors) that counts.
hero.direction: Terms to keep in mind while you shop

inspiration.heading: Hollow Core
copy: Spoiler alert: hollow core doors aren’t hollow inside. They’re actually filled with a corrugated honeycomb recycled material. This filler makes them lightweight, light on your wallet...but light on noise cancelling.

inspiration.heading: Solid Core
copy: Solid core doors feel heavy in your hand, like solid wood. They’re filled with a low-density eco-friendly material that reduces sound transmission by 50 percent.

next.heading: Now, let’s go over your environmentally friendly options.
next.copy: Make sure your interior doors have a positive impact on the environment, both inside and outside your home.

hero.heading: Interior Doors Checklist
hero.copy: Interior doors can blend into your decor or make a statement. When selecting yours, think about what level of privacy you need between rooms and how much space you’ll need for door opening and foot traffic.
hero.direction: How to shop for interior doors

cards.title: Start with the basics.
cards.copy: Not sure where to begin? By the end of this guide you should be able to walk into a store with an idea of what you want.

cards.title: Make your own checklist.
cards.copy: As you’re learning about interior doors, use our checklist to keep track of things you’d like to discuss with a Lowe’s specialist.

cards.title: When you’re ready, talk to us.
cards.copy: We’ve got experts ready to help you in the Doors aisle. We can give you an installation quote while you’re there.

inspiration.heading: Consider going pro.
copy: Skip the hassle of needing to accurately measure your interior door.
You don’t have to worry about accidentally voiding your warranty.
A pro will clean up the mess and dispose of your old door.

outro.heading: If you go DIY, here’s how to measure your interior door.

cards.title: Width
cards.copy: Measure the distance between the edge of one side of the door to the edge of the other side of the door.

cards.title: Height
cards.copy: Next, measure the distance between the top edge of the door to the bottom edge of the door.

cards.title: Depth
cards.copy: Measure the width of the frame, from edge to edge, across the existing door frame. Ignore any door trim.

next.heading: Learn about our different types of interior doors.
next.copy: Consider how much space you need to open and close your door, and how much privacy you need between rooms when looking for the right interior door.

hero.heading: Panel Model
hero.copy: Explore panel design options for your interior door’s look, texture, privacy level and personality.
hero.direction: Picture your door with these panel options

inspiration.heading: Paneled
copy: Going for a classic Shaker look? Prefer a clean, minimalist design? These wood and wood composite panel options offer crafted stiles and rails, moulding, embossing, paintable surfaces and natural wood looks.

inspiration.heading: Glass
copy: Get a clear view from room to room, or spread light between spaces with glass panels. They come in a variety of sizes, shapes, textures, colors and patterns.

inspiration.heading: Louvered
copy: These slatted panels allow for airflow and ventilation without sacrificing your privacy. Full- and half-louvered panel options are available in wood.

inspiration.heading: Flush
copy: Keep it clean and simple with these durable, practical and low-maintenance panel designs. Show  off the natural beauty of the woodgrain with veneer options, or opt for paintable hardboard.

inspiration.heading: Chalkboard & Mirrored
copy: Personalize your interior doors with alternative surfaces. Get creative with the chalkboard option, or use the mirrored surface wherever you need to catch a view.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen Molded Impression Mirror Pocket Bathroom Door

next.heading: Now, let’s talk about your door’s appearance.
next.copy: From the frame to the finish, your interior doors can be customized to reflect your personal style.

hero.heading: Safety
hero.copy: Hopefully you never have to worry about a fire in your home, but it’s always better to be prepared.
hero.direction: Here’s what to know about safety.

inspiration.heading: Fire-rated doors
copy: The purpose of a fire-rated door is not only to keep fire out but to give you time to leave or get help. A fire rating tells you how long the door takes to burn. Your options range from 20 to 90 minutes, depending on the door.

next.heading: Before you start shopping, let’s make a checklist.
next.copy: Why not get your ideas down while they’re fresh before you head into a store?

hero.heading: Sliding & Folding
hero.copy: If you’re looking to save space and add style, these sliding and folding doors offer form and function.
hero.direction: See your sliding and folding door options

inspiration.heading: Sliding/Bypass
copy: When it comes to space-saving minimalism, these doors will keep you on track. Two doors slide past each other on a quiet track system that’s easy to install.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen Moda White Pocket Hallway Door Sliding

inspiration.heading: Bi-fold closet
copy: Perfect for closets, laundry rooms and any room that’s subtly tucked away, these narrow doors fold up on a track when open, using less space than a traditional hinged door.

next.heading: Next, let’s go over specialty doors.
next.copy: These distinctive, space-saving door types are a great way to give your place a little character.

hero.heading: Specialty
hero.copy: These distinctive, space-saving door types are a great way to give your place a little character.
hero.direction: What to know about specialty doors

inspiration.heading: Barn
copy: From rustic charm to sleek and modern, barn doors offer bold style and a casual way to separate spaces. They hang from an overhead track and float over the door opening—different from the full close of a hinged door—and come in one- or two-door sets.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen Painted Molded Madison Barn Door

inspiration.heading: Pocket
copy: A popular choice for parlor rooms in Victorian days, pocket doors open by sliding into a slot in the wall, where they stay tucked away. They use less space than hinged doors and come in single and double configurations.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen MODA White Pocket Hallway Door

next.heading: Next, let’s go over your style options.
next.copy: Cultivate your look with the right panel model, appearance and finishing touches.

hero.heading: Wood Composite
hero.copy: Wood composite doors are engineered to give you the best of wood and the best of technology.
hero.direction: Why choose a wood composite door?

inspiration.heading: Classic look & new tech
copy: Solid wood is naturally attractive but does have some drawbacks. Wood composite doors can look and feel like solid wood but can be much stronger and usually cost less. Plus, you can choose from a wide range of veneers, textures, weights and panel designs.

inspiration.heading: Eco-friendly
copy: Underneath their veneers, wood composite doors are mostly made up of recycled material that has been moulded into your desired shape

inspiration.heading: Strength & durability
copy: Solid wood doors are good at resisting warping, shrinking and cracking. But thanks to engineering innovations, wood composite doors are even better at it.

next.heading: Next, let’s go over MDF.
next.copy: Medium density fiberboard is a durable material made from recycled wood fibers and resin.

hero.heading: Wood
hero.copy: Wood interior doors are crafted to complement your home’s architectural style and personal aesthetic.
hero.direction: Why choose wood interior doors?

inspiration.heading: Strength & beauty
copy: Solid wood doors have been the standard for centuries—the high end look that other materials imitate. It’s strong and secure yet warm and inviting, with distinctive color and variation in each species.

inspiration.heading: Lasting durability
copy: Wear and tear are no match for solid wood. Compared to other materials, it’s the least likely to dent and scratches are easy to repair.

inspiration.heading: Quality & craftsmanship
copy: Centuries of craftsmanship have been passed down and improved upon in today’s interior doors. With professionally crafted styles and custom wood options, you’re bound to find the look you’re after.

next.heading: Next, let’s talk about wood composite.
next.copy: Wood composite doors are engineered to give you the best of wood and the best of technology.

hero.heading: Appearance
hero.copy: From the frame to the finish, your patio door can be customized to reflect your personal style.
hero.direction: Consider how style affects your door’s appearance

inspiration.heading: Frame
copy: To complete your patio door’s look, you can add trim or a customized casing pattern for a bold and refined look.

inspiration.heading: Panel design
copy: Do you want a traditional panel design, like French doors? Or a more contemporary design? How will the panels complement the frame material? Will they be flat or raised to match existing molding?

small.alt: Jeld-Wen 8-lite Simulated Divided Lite with Low-E glass

inspiration.heading: Color
copy: Your color options will vary based on your frame material. Generally, darker colors absorb heat while lighter colors reflect heat. It might be something to consider if you live in an area with extreme temps.

inspiration.heading: Texture
copy: Want your patio to set a precedent for modern minimalists? Opt for smooth metal textures. Want your patio to have that old-world charm? The distressed wood look should set the tone.

inspiration.heading: Protective finishes
copy: Some exterior door frames come with a protective finish already. These finishes make maintenance a breeze and help prevent fading and rusting. Pre-primed options are also available for do-it-yourself painting or staining.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen Painted Steel Swinging Patio Door Finish

next.heading: Next, let’s go over a few finishing touches.
next.copy: Don’t treat these details as afterthoughts. This is where style and function collide.

We recommend taking photos of your patio doors and bringing them along. Selfies are welcome.

next.heading: Ready to talk patio doors? So are we.

hero.heading: Clad-wood
hero.copy: One side of a clad-wood frame grows on trees while the other side is made in a factory. Clad-wood is low-maintenance and versatile.
hero.direction: Why choose clad-wood?

inspiration.heading: The easy maintenance
copy: The exterior frame material acts like a suit of armor for the wood inside. The protective finish makes it easy to care for. No repainting required.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen W-2500 Aluminum Clad Wood Sliding Patio Door

inspiration.heading: The best of both worlds
copy: Your patio door’s interior frame can be matched to any wood trim or molding inside your home while you enjoy the benefits of a metal or fiberglass exterior.

inspiration.heading: When to choose wood
copy: Since wood frames need more upkeep, most people only choose wood if they live in a historic home. Though, wood innately has grain color and texture that other materials just imitate. Plus, scratches are easy to repair.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen W-4500. Wood Sliding Patio Door

next.heading: Next, let’s talk about fiberglass.
next.copy: Fiberglass frames are durable, low maintenance and can even look like wood.

hero.heading: Durability & Impact
hero.copy: From hurricane debris to the decibels of a passing airplane, there are ways to measure what can get through your door.
hero.direction: Here are some things to consider when you shop

inspiration.heading: Impact resistance
copy: Depending on your building code, you may be required to have impact-resistant glass. This type of glass has a layer of polymer between the glass that can withstand wind, water and debris. Plus, it won’t shatter if it breaks.

inspiration.heading: Noise reduction
copy: The number of panes, types of coating and layers of insulation all factor into how much noise can travel through your door. A door’s Sound Transmission Class (STC) rating will tell you how many decibels make it through the threshold.

next.heading: Now let’s take a look at your safety and privacy options.
next.copy: From dead bolts to smart home sensors, you don’t ever have to second guess your patio door’s security.

hero.heading: Energy Efficiency
hero.copy: Energy efficiency matters if you’re looking to save money on bills or maximize the comfort of your home.
hero.direction: Here are terms to remember while you shop

inspiration.heading: Triple pane & low-E glass
copy: Triple pane glass can be filled with gas that makes it hard for heat and humidity to pass through, which helps you cut your energy costs. Low-E glass has an invisible metallic coating that keeps heat inside during winter and outside during summer. Both types of glass will help cut your energy costs.

inspiration.heading: UV coating fade protection
copy: Vinyl patio doors are always UV-coated to protect against fading. You can also get UV-coated glass that acts like sunscreen for furniture inside your home.

inspiration.heading: U-factor & Solar Heat Gain Coefficient (SHGC)
copy: The lower the U-factor, the less heat and cold can transfer through the door. A lower SHGC means there are fewer UV rays passing through the glass. They’re both helpful factors in finding doors that meet ENERGY STAR® requirements for your region.

inspiration.heading: Screens
copy: To take advantage of great weather and save on heat or air, a screen will allow you to open your patio door while keeping bugs out.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen V-2500 Vinyl Sliding Patio Door Pet Door

next.heading: Now, let’s talk about your patio door’s durability.
next.copy: From hurricane debris to the decibels of a passing airplane, there are ways to measure what can get through your door.

hero.heading: Fiberglass
hero.copy: Fiberglass doors are durable, low maintenance and can even look like wood or steel.
hero.direction: Why choose fiberglass patio doors?

inspiration.heading: It’s durable.
copy: Do you live in a particularly hot, cold, wet or dry climate? Fiberglass is designed to withstand both ends of the weather spectrum without warping or rotting. And it won’t dent, either.

small.alt: Pella IM Fiberglass Patio Door COB

inspiration.heading: It’s low maintenance.
copy: Because of its baked-on protective finish, you won’t need to refinish or repaint it as it ages. It’s also easy to clean.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen Painted Smooth Fiberglass Swinging Patio Doors

inspiration.heading: It’s versatile in style.
copy: Right down to the knots, cracks and colors, fiberglass can be made to look like real wood. Smooth white and paintable finishes also make it a dent-resistant steel alternative. Your guests will be none the wiser.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen Stained Oak Fiberglass Swinging Patio Doors

next.heading: Next, let’s discuss the benefits of vinyl.
next.copy: Vinyl is a low-maintenance material formulated to look great for years to come.

hero.heading: Finishing Touches
hero.copy: Don’t treat these details as afterthoughts. This is where style and function collide.
hero.direction: Finishing touches make a world of difference

inspiration.heading: Add on the charm.
copy: If you’re serious about "old-world" charm, a few well-placed clavos and corner blocks can take your door from run-of-the-mill to Renaissance.

inspiration.heading: Choose hassle-free blinds.
copy: Blinds can be troublesome between kids, pets and dust, but they provide much-needed shade. Blinds installed between the glass give you fingertip control without any of the hassle.

inspiration.heading: A polished look hinges on hardware.
copy: Choosing the right hardware for your door comes down to style as much as function. Do you want a handle that’s sleek and mostly hidden or one that stands out? Do you want hinges that contrast or blend with your frame?

next.heading: Next up, let’s look at your material options.
next.copy: When you’re considering materials, think about the level of maintenance and overall look you’re after.

hero.heading: Folding
hero.copy: These doors are designed for large openings and fold away neatly to blur the line between indoors and outdoors.
hero.direction: Take a closer look at folding patio doors

inspiration.heading: Double
copy: Double folding doors fold away nicely to make space for furniture and foot traffic. You can fold both doors away to the same side of the doorway or fold one to each side.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen W-4500 Wood 2-Panel Folding Patio Door

inspiration.heading: Multi
copy: The more panels you have, the more natural light fills your indoor space. These can even fold around 90 degree corners to maximize the width of your patio opening.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen W-4500 Wood Folding Patio Doors

next.heading: Next, let’s go over your sliding patio door options.
next.copy: These low-maintenance, easy-to-open, space-saving doors won’t interfere with your feng shui.

hero.heading: Glass
hero.copy: Elevate your space with handcrafted decorative patio door glass that adds texture, privacy and personality.
hero.direction: Picture your patio with these glass options

inspiration.heading: Decorative glass
copy: Unexpected glass details, like beveling, can enhance your patio’s atmosphere. The design you choose creates depth, contrast, and can add a certain amount of privacy.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen Painted Steel Swinging Patio Door with Deco Glass

inspiration.heading: Clear vs. textured
copy: Clear glass is great when you have a stellar view from your patio. If your view comes second to privacy, glass textures like rain glass and granite glass add distinction and distortion.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen Painted Steel Swinging Patio Door

inspiration.heading: Privacy rating
copy: The higher the privacy rating the more privacy the glass offers. Zero means it’s transparent. Ten is the most opaque option, blurring the view  from outside to give you more privacy.

inspiration.heading: Grilles
copy: Low-maintenance internal grilles add a nice design element, while external grilles have a more substantial, traditional look. Removable grilles offer easy snap-on, snap-off versatility.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen 10-Lite Double Doors with Clear Transom

next.heading: Now, let’s talk more about your patio door’s appearance.
next.copy: From the frame to the finish, your patio door can be customized to reflect your personal style.

hero.heading: Hinged
hero.copy: These open like other doors in your home since they pivot out from one side, allowing for a wide open doorway.
hero.direction: View all of our hinged patio doors

inspiration.heading: Single
copy: A single hinged door adds ventilation and blends in well with other exterior doors in most traditional homes.

inspiration.heading: Double
copy: Also called French doors, double hinged doors are a great way to add a bit of drama and more sunlight to a room.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen Painted Steel Swinging Double Patio Door

inspiration.heading: Something to consider.
copy: Whether your patio door swings in or out, make sure that no furniture will prevent it from opening all the way.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen Painted Steel Swinging Patio Door Deco Glass

next.heading: Next, let’s take a look at your folding patio door options.
next.copy: If wide open space is what you’re after, a folding door system will open your room up to the great outdoors.

hero.heading: Patio Doors Checklist
hero.copy: A patio door is your family’s gateway to outdoor celebrations and relaxation. Let us help you find the right one, so you can start celebrating and relaxing sooner.
hero.direction: How to shop for patio doors

cards.title: Start with the basics.
cards.copy: Not sure where to begin? By the end of this guide you should be able to walk into a store with an idea of what you want.

cards.title: Make your own checklist.
cards.copy: As you’re learning about patio doors, use our checklist to keep track of things you’d like to discuss with a Lowe’s sales associate.

cards.title: When you’re ready, talk to us.
cards.copy: We’ve got patio door experts ready to help you in our store. We can give you an installation quote while you’re there.

inspiration.heading: Consider Going Pro
copy: Skip the hassle of needing to accurately measure your patio door and frame.
You don’t have to worry about accidentally voiding your warranty.
A pro will clean up the mess and dispose of your old patio door.

outro.heading: If you go DIY, here’s how to measure your patio door.

cards.title: Width
cards.copy: Measure distance between the side door jambs at three points: the top, middle and bottom of the patio door opening.

cards.title: Height
cards.copy: Next, measure the distance between the top of the head jamb to the top of the bottom sill at three points: far left, center, and far right.

cards.title: Depth
cards.copy: Measure the width of the jamb, from edge to edge, across the existing door frame. Ignore any door trim.

next.heading: Learn about our different types of patio doors.
next.copy: When you’re thinking about your patio door type, consider the amount of sunlight and open space you have now versus the amount you’d like to have.

hero.heading: Safety & Privacy
hero.copy: From dead bolts to blinds, you don’t ever have to second guess your patio door’s security.
hero.direction: These features will help you rest easy.

inspiration.heading: Multi-point hardware
copy: For peace of mind, you can install a secure handle and multiple locks at the top, bottom, and middle of your door.

inspiration.heading: Dead bolts and foot bolts
copy: The standard in security is the deadbolt. A foot bolt is great if you’d like to crack open your door but keep it from opening all the way. You need a key to unlock a deadbolt, whereas foot bolts can be unlocked from inside.

inspiration.heading: Remote control blinds and shades
copy: Blinds can be either manual or remote controlled. You can even have sensors installed that notify you via your smartphone whenever your patio door is open.

next.heading: Before you head into a store, let’s make a checklist.
next.copy: Get your ideas down while they’re fresh. Then shopping will be a breeze.

hero.heading: Sliding
hero.copy: These low-maintenance, easy-to-open, space-saving doors won’t interfere with your feng shui.
hero.direction: What to know about sliding patio doors

inspiration.heading: Single
copy: A single sliding door can imitate the look of a French swinging door but give you the benefit of added space. Only one panel slides open.

large.alt: Jeld-Wen V-2500 Vinyl Sliding Patio Door

inspiration.heading: Double
copy: If you need a little more ventilation and sunlight, try a double sliding door, since the panels stack behind one another.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen W-4500 Wood Sliding Patio Door

inspiration.heading: Multi
copy: If you really want your indoor and outdoor spaces to blend into one another, you can add as many sliding doors as your house’s structure allows.

next.heading: Next, let’s go over some of your patio door style options.
next.copy: Elevate your space with handcrafted decorative patio door glass that adds texture, privacy and personality.

hero.heading: Steel
hero.copy: Steel is great if you’re looking for a modern metal door that’s as easy on the eyes as it is to maintain.
hero.direction: Why choose steel?

inspiration.heading: It won’t warp or rot.
copy: Unlike wood, steel is mostly weather-resistant. And it’s typically less costly and less work to maintain.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen Steel Swinging Patio Door Blinds Between Glass

inspiration.heading: It’s great at insulating.
copy: Steel patio doors have insulated cores and therefore tend to be more energy efficient.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen Steel Swinging Patio Door Deco

next.heading: Next up, let’s look at your performance options.
next.copy: There’s more to your patio door than just good looks. It can reduce your energy costs, drown out street noise, and more.

hero.heading: Vinyl
hero.copy: Vinyl is an energy efficient, low-maintenance material formulated to look great for years to come.
hero.direction: Why go with vinyl?

inspiration.heading: The color is permanent.
copy: Vinyl comes in several colors, none of which will fade thanks to a meticulous design process. Vinyl will also never flake, peel or rot.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen Painted Steel Swinging Patio Door Vinyl

inspiration.heading: It’s low maintenance.
copy: You probably guessed as much by now, but vinyl is easy to care for. Some vinyl patio doors are even reinforced with metal on the inside to prevent warping as they age.

small.alt: Pella TS Vinyl Patio Door beauty

large.alt: Jeld-Wen V-2500 Vinyl Sliding Patio Door with Pet Door

next.heading: Next, let’s talk about the benefits of steel.
next.copy: Steel is great if you’re looking for a modern metal door that’s as easy on the eyes as it is to maintain.

hero.heading: Aluminum
hero.copy: Aluminum windows are known for being low maintenance, weather-resistant and easy to open.
hero.direction: Why choose aluminum windows?

cards.copy: Aluminum will never rot or corrode over time. This makes it an excellent option in coastal areas.
Because they don’t corrode and are easy to clean, they’re incredibly low maintenance.
Because aluminum is almost as strong as steel but weighs a lot less, these windows are durable yet easy to open.

inspiration.heading: Aluminum
copy: Today’s aluminum windows are a vast improvement over their predecessors from the 70’s.

small.alt: Jeld-Wen Aluminum Double-Hung Obscure Textured Window

next.heading: Next, see how window performance can improve your home.
next.copy: Windows can do everything from lower your energy bill to minimize street noise.

hero.direction: Tell us about your project

content: A professional will accurately measure your windows for you.
You don't have to worry about accidentally voiding your warranty.
We'll clean up the mess and dispose of your old windows for you.

instruction.title: Measurements
content: Doing it yourself? You can add your window sizes below.
We recommend taking photos of your windows and bringing them along. Selfies are welcome.

next.heading: Ready to talk windows? So are we.

hero.heading: Clad-wood & Wood
hero.copy: With clad-wood you can enjoy the character of wood and the energy-efficiency of vinyl, fiberglass or aluminum.
hero.direction: Why choose clad-wood or wood windows?

inspiration.heading: Clad-wood
copy: You have free reign over the stain and finish of the interior wood frame, while the weather-resistant exterior frame gives you peace of mind.

large.alt: Jeld-Wen Aluminum Clad Wood Double Hung Window

inspiration.heading: Wood
copy: While wood windows require a bit of maintenance, they go a long way in preserving the character of historic homes.

large.alt: Pella IM Fiberglass Window COB Wood Double Hung Window

next.heading: Next up, aluminum windows.
next.copy: Aluminum windows are known for being low maintenance, weather-resistant and easy to open.

hero.heading: Combinations
hero.copy: You can combine different types of windows to complement a home’s overall design. Here’s how to pull off some of the most popular architectural styles.
hero.direction: View all of our combination windows

cards.copy: You can mix and match common window shapes and sizes to create unique designs
Keep ventilation in mind when designing your window combinations.
Make sure all the windows in each combination are the same depth.

inspiration.heading: Victorian
copy: This look is all about balancing bold statements with intricate details. The more ornate the better.

inspiration.heading: Modern
copy: Open spaces. Clean lines. Lots of natural light. It’s all about bringing the outdoors inside.

inspiration.heading: Craftsman
copy: The curb appeal of a Craftsman bungalow home comes from its balanced sections of wood, brick and glass.

next.heading: Now, the fun really starts with glass options.
next.copy: We could write a book about glass options, but we’ll just show you our favorites.

hero.heading: Energy Efficiency
hero.copy: New windows can cut down on your energy bill and your carbon footprint.
hero.direction: View all of our energy efficient windows

inspiration.heading: Number of panes
copy: Multiple panes of glass with air or gas in between them do a much better job insulating your home than just one pane. They also help with noise cancelling.

inspiration.heading: Energy Star®
copy: ENERGY STAR certified windows meet all the strict energy efficiency guidelines set by the Environmental Protection Agency. There are different certification requirements for different climate zones.

link.text: Find out which zone you're in.

inspiration.heading: Gas fills & glass coating
copy: Some windows have gases between the panes that are better at insulating than regular air.
You can also opt for low-e glass, which means it’s been treated to keep heat inside during winter and outside during summer.

small.alt: Pella Sliding Window Gas Fill Coating

inspiration.heading: Screens
copy: Screens are great at keeping bugs out and keeping harsh heat and sunlight at bay. Your screen can cover half or all of your window—some even retract.

next.heading: Next, let’s go over your window style options.
next.copy: From grilles to glass texture, personal touches go a long way in tying your home’s look together.

hero.heading: Fiberglass
hero.copy: These cutting-edge windows are known for their longevity, durability and energy-efficiency.
hero.direction: Why choose fiberglass windows?

cards.copy: They’ll keep your room temperatures even and can help you lower your energy bill.
They’re incredibly strong and can handle all kinds of weather. And they don’t need a lot of maintenance.
They last longer than vinyl windows because fiberglass doesn’t expand or contract as much. This makes for a stronger seal.

inspiration.heading: Fiberglass windows are built to impress.

next.heading: Next up, let’s talk clad-wood and wood.
next.copy: With clad-wood, you can enjoy the character of wood and the energy-efficiency of vinyl, fiberglass or aluminum.

hero.heading: Frame Options
hero.copy: From super sleek to over-the-top, don’t underestimate how impactful window frames can be.
hero.direction: View all of our frame options

inspiration.heading: Interior trim options
copy: Extension jambs emphasize the depth of your window by covering the gap between your wall and your window. Think reading nook or built-in shelving.
For added flair, choose contrasting window trim and frame materials, like aluminum and wood.
Thick wooden trim complements homes adorned with crown moulding and baseboards.

inspiration.heading: Exterior trim options
copy: Add intrigue to your curb appeal with trims that are cut at an angle or feature molding.
Contrasting colors draw the eye in and make windows appear bigger than they really are.
You can opt for minimal window trim and make another feature of your house the focal point.

inspiration.heading: Wood finishes
copy: Most wood and wood-clad windows come unfinished so that you can add your own personal touch. But before you stain or finish your window, read your warranty to make sure you don’t accidentally void it.

inspiration.heading: Interior colors
copy: There are two sides to every window. The inside can be a different color than the outside. Use the décor in your home as inspiration for what color you’d like your windows to be. Or vice versa.

inspiration.heading: Exterior
copy: Do you want your windows to pop or blend in with the rest of your home? Will the frames be surrounded by trim? Will they match or contrast? Your home is a canvas. And you’re the artist.

items: Profiles can elevate the look of your window combinations.
They tie door frames and window frames together.
They can even cover an entire wall, if you’d like.

next.heading: Before you start shopping, let’s make a checklist.
next.copy: Get your ideas down while they’re fresh before you head into a store.

hero.heading: Glass Options
hero.copy: We could write a book just about glass options, but instead we’ll just show you some of our favorites.
hero.direction: Grille type & patterns

cards.copy: Grilles come in varying widths and materials.
Exterior grilles offer a more traditional look while interior grills are low maintenance and easy to clean.
You can choose from existing patterns or create your own design.

inspiration.heading: Tinted
copy: These days there are tinted glass and even glass adhesive films that block harsh UV rays and sun glare. You can have your pick of hues like bronze, platinum, silver and blue.

inspiration.heading: Beveled
copy: If your window is the focal point in a room, beveled glass is a great way to elevate your space. You can keep it simple or create a true work of art inside your window frame.

inspiration.heading: Obscured
copy: If you’d like natural light to fill a room but maintain your privacy, like, say, in a bathroom, we recommend choosing obscured glass.

large.alt: Jeld-Wen Aluminum Double Hung Obscure Textured

inspiration.heading: Textured
copy: Add natural light, privacy and personality with textured glass. It’s a nice detail that can create a striking focal point in a room. You can even mix and match multiple textures on a single pane.

large.alt: Jeld-Wen Vinyl Single-Hung Textured Rain Glass

outro.heading: Here are a few popular grille patterns:

next.heading: Now let’s take a look at your frame options.
next.copy: From super sleek to over-the-top, don’t underestimate how impactful window frames can be.

hero.heading: Hinged
hero.copy: For rooms that need extra ventilation, these are your best option.
hero.direction: View all of our hinged windows

inspiration.heading: Casement
copy: These are hinged on one side and pivot out at the other end for ventilation. Think of them like mini-doors. Some even have hand-cranks that make them even easier to open.

inspiration.heading: Awning
copy: Since these are hinged at the top and open outward, they’ll keep the rain out when they’re open during an afternoon shower.

next.heading: Next, let’s go over your specialty window options.
next.copy: Add character to your home with windows that stand out.

hero.heading: Impact
hero.copy: Whether you’re worried about weather, neighbors or intruders, there’s a way to keep the world outside at bay.
hero.direction: What are your window impact must-haves?

inspiration.heading: Laminated
copy: Live in a hurricane zone? Worried about security? Laminated glass is shatterproof and absorbs impact, whether it’s from debris or a crowbar. Even if it breaks, it stays in one piece.

inspiration.heading: Security
copy: Screens. Locks. Bars. Films. We can help you choose the right device to make sure your windows aren’t the weakest link in your security chain.

inspiration.heading: Noise cancelling
copy: Is the neighbor’s kid practicing drums before school? Is that train waking you up at night? We’ve got noise cancelling window inserts that will help you get the beauty sleep you and your family deserve.

next.heading: Next, let’s go over some window safety options.
next.copy: Because it’s always better to be prepared, and up to code.

hero.heading: Windows Checklist
hero.copy: We’ll level with you. Shopping for windows can be overwhelming, especially if it’s your first time – or first time in a while. We’re here to help make it easy.
hero.direction: How to shop for windows

cards.title: Start with the basics.
cards.copy: Shopping for windows can be overwhelming. This guide breaks down technical terms like “low-E” and “laminated.”

cards.title: Make your own checklist.
cards.copy: As you’re learning about your window options, feel free to use our checklist to keep track of things you’d like to discuss with a pro.

cards.title: When you’re ready, talk to us.
cards.copy: We’ve got window experts ready to help you in the Windows aisle. Or you can even schedule a free in-home consultation.

inspiration.heading: Consider Going Pro
copy: Skip the hassle of needing to accurately measure your windows.
You don’t have to worry about accidentally voiding your warranty.
A pro will clean up the mess and dispose of your old window.

outro.heading: If you choose to go DIY, here's how to measure your window.

cards.title: Width
cards.copy: You’re going to measure the jambs at three points: the top, middle and bottom of the window opening. Start by measuring from the surface of the jambs, not the trim strips or parting beads in your window opening. Use the smallest of these three measurements to order your new window.

cards.title: Height
cards.copy: Next, measure from the top inside surface of the sill of your window opening. Then make three measurements: one at the left side, the center and the right side of the window. Use the smallest of these three height measurements to order your new window.

cards.title: Depth
cards.copy: When you’re measuring depth, just ignore any pulleys or parting strips, since they'll be removed later. There needs to be at least 3 1/4 inches of opening depth between the inside window trim and the outside blind stop strip. This is so there’s enough room for the replacement window.

next.heading: Learn about our different types of windows.
next.copy: Some windows open sideways. Some don’t open at all. Some are big and some are small.

hero.heading: Safety
hero.copy: Because it’s always better to be prepared, and up to code.
hero.direction: What are your window safety must-haves?

inspiration.heading: Tempered
copy: Tempered glass is almost 5x stronger than normal glass. That’s why a lot of people like to have tempered glass windows in areas where people frequently hang out at home. Also, some building codes require you to have tempered glass.

inspiration.heading: Window opening control device
copy: The same way a child safety lock can control a door’s ability to open, window opening control devices can prevent accidental falls and other hazards by limiting how far a window can be opened. Some building codes require these, too.

large.alt: Jeld-wen Wood Window Opening Control Device

next.heading: Next, learn all about energy efficiency.
next.copy: New windows can cut down on your carbon footprint and your energy bill.

windowsSections.question: What window materials are you considering?

windowsSections.question: What style options would you like to discuss?

hero.heading: Sliding
hero.copy: These are easy to open and give you good ventilation and open horizontally or vertically.
hero.direction: View all of our sliding windows

inspiration.heading: Single-hung
copy: If only one panel of glass moves up and down, we call that a single-hung window. It doesn’t provide as much ventilation as a double-hung, but if you have multiple single-hungs in a room, you get a nice cross-breeze.

inspiration.heading: Double-hung
copy: If both panels of glass move up and down, we call that double-hung. They’re easier to to clean than single-hung and give better ventilation since hot air goes out the top panel and cool air comes in through the bottom panel.

inspiration.heading: Horizontal Sliding
copy: If your window is in an area where sliding a window open vertically might be a challenge, try a horizontal sliding window.

next.heading: Next, let’s take a look at your hinged window options.
next.copy: For rooms that need extra ventilation, hinged windows are your best option.

hero.heading: Specialty
hero.copy: Add character to your home with windows that stand out.
hero.direction: View all of our specialty windows

inspiration.heading: Bay
copy: Bay comes from a French word meaning “opening”. And that’s just what these windows do to a room — open it up.

inspiration.heading: Bow
copy: Bow windows are like bay windows, only they create a subtler opening with wider angles between the glass panes.

inspiration.heading: Picture
copy: Sometimes the simplest design is the best. Picture, or fixed, windows let tons of light into the room yet are surprisingly energy efficient.

inspiration.heading: Special shapes
copy: Here’s the long and short of it: your window can be any shape you want it to be. Octagon? Rombus? You got it.

next.heading: Next, let’s go over your frame material options.
next.copy: Your windows are made of more than just glass. Here are some things to keep in mind when you go into a store.

hero.heading: Vinyl
hero.copy: This versatile material is known for being low maintenance and energy efficient.
hero.direction: Why choose vinyl windows?

cards.copy: Vinyl windows come in dozens of colors that will never fade because the color is part of the material itself.
They’re easy to clean and virtually scratch-resistant. Children’s play room? Cat’s favorite spot? Vinyl can handle it.
They’re great at insulating and cutting down on condensation. Goodbye foggy windows. Hello lower energy bill.

inspiration.heading: New vinyl windows can really make a room come together.

next.heading: Next, let’s go over fiberglass windows.
next.copy: These cutting-edge windows are known for their longevity and energy-efficiency.
